channel.title: Powershell on Coding notes
channel.description: Recent content in Powershell on Coding notes

item.title: Install azcopy in windows from powershell
item.description: Install func cli $InstallPath = 'C:\AzCopy' # Cleanup Destination if (Test-Path $InstallPath) { Get-ChildItem $InstallPath | Remove-Item -Confirm:$false -Force } # Zip Destination $zip = "$InstallPath\AzCopy.Zip" # Create the installation folder (eg. C:\AzCopy) $null = New-Item -Type Directory -Path $InstallPath -Force # Download AzCopy zip for Windows Start-BitsTransfer -Source "https://aka.ms/downloadazcopy-v10-windows" -Destination $zip # Expand the Zip file Expand-Archive $zip $InstallPath -Force # Move to $InstallPath Get-ChildItem "$($InstallPath)\*\*" | Move-Item -Destination "$($InstallPath)\" -Force #Cleanup - delete ZIP and old folder Remove-Item $zip -Force -Confirm:$false Get-ChildItem "$($InstallPath)\*" -Directory | ForEach-Object { Remove-Item $_.

item.title: Query sql server from powershell
item.description: Query sqlserver powershell module Install-Module sqlserver -Force A minimun nuget version is required. A messages provides the command to install it if was required. Run query Invoke-Sqlcmd -Query "SELECT GETDATE() AS TimeOfQuery" -ServerInstance "localhost" Run script Invoke-Sqlcmd -InputFile "C:\setupscripts\createUser.sql" | Out-File -FilePath "C:\setupscripts\createUser.log"

item.title: Install sql server unattended from Powershell
item.description: Download installation from here, run it and use the option Download Media. To install Express edition, run powershell as admin and go cd C:\SQL2019\SQLEXPR_x64_ENU .\setup.exe /Q /HIDECONSOLE=0 /ACTION=INSTALL /SUPPRESSPRIVACYSTATEMENTNOTICE /IACCEPTSQLSERVERLICENSETERMS=1 /FEATURES=SQLENGINE /UPDATEENABLED=0 /INSTANCENAME="MSSQLSERVER" /ADDCURRENTUSERASSQLADMIN=1 /SECURITYMODE=SQL /SKIPRULES=RebootRequiredCheck /SAPWD="Pasword_01" /SQLSVCSTARTUPTYPE=AUTOMATIC /INDICATEPROGRESS For Developer edition, run powershell as admin and go cd C:\SQL2019\Developer_ENU .\setup.exe /q /ACTION=Install /INSTANCENAME=MSSQLSERVER /FEATURES=SQLEngine /UPDATEENABLED=0 /SQLSVCACCOUNT='NT AUTHORITY\NETWORK SERVICE' /SQLSYSADMINACCOUNTS='BUILTIN\ADMINISTRATORS' /TCPENABLED=1 /NPENABLED=0 /IACCEPTSQLSERVERLICENSETERMS /INDICATEPROGRESS /SECURITYMODE=SQL /SAPWD="Password_01" To uninstall .\setup.exe /q /ACTION=Uninstall /INSTANCENAME=MSSQLSERVER /FEATURES=SQLEngine /INDICATEPROGRESS

item.title: Powershell cheatsheet
item.description: Bypass digitally sign constrain for scripts execution Run powershell as Administrator. Set-ExecutionPolicy -ExecutionPolicy Unrestricted List environment variables Get-ChildItem -Path Env:\ Also, using .net from powershell, and specifying system-level variables, by specifying machine as second argument. This argument could also be user [System.Environment]::GetEnvironmentVariable('VARIABLE_NAME','machine') For some reason, the previous doesn’t work for variable COMPUTERNAME. To get computer name: $env:computername Set environment variable Run powershell as Admin. new variable [System.Environment]::SetEnvironmentVariable('VARIABLE_NAME', 'VARIABLE_VALUE',[System.EnvironmentVariableTarget]::Machine) add to an existing variable (typically to PATH) $current=[System.
